people_also_viewed.summary:
Freedom Preetham
        
              
          Recently, I was casually asked if I could build autonomous vehicle fleets end-to-end as a business case, more from an engineering stack perspective. My modest answer is, "Yes, maybe", (safety and on-vehicle AI stack is the toughest in this domain), (The engineering-stack playbook for this is sorta written even though not fully complete. I’ll share my thoughts on AI side of things soon). IMO, one aspect that is missing is a geo-fenced, peer-to-peer network which should add a layer of resilience and reduce latency compared to current playbook.

But that conversation left me with a far more interesting question: Could we conceive of a harder challenge? What about an autonomous drone navigating high vortex wind fields? (just fun thought experiment)

The more I think about it, the clearer it becomes that this problem, and many others like it, exposes fundamental flaws in how we approach AI today. It demands a return to first principles. Back to the drawing board.

The first among many things that must change is how we do reinforcement learning (RL). The current state of RL is still predominantly discretized, and that is fundamentally inefficient.

Here is a blog that outlines my perspective on why RL needs an update and what could happen if we rethink its foundations.

#ReinforcementLearning #ArtificialIntelligence #AutonomousNavigation

Xiaotian Xu
        
              
          Ever heard of "scrna-tools.org"? It lists over 1,800 single-cell analysis tools! 😅  This is just one example of the duplication crisis plaguing computational biology research.
A recent article by Jake Taylor-King explores how academic publishing incentives drive researchers to publish "slightly different" versions of existing work instead of building upon it. She listed the aftermath of the duplication: 1. Fragmented knowledge: Mountains of papers with minimal advancements. ️2. Wasted resources: Endless repetition of efforts instead of collaboration.
3. Slow progress: Difficulty in building upon existing research hinders innovation.
But can we change the incentive system itself? The article suggests allowing updates to existing papers and evolving authorship to foster collaboration.
What do you think about the duplication crisis? How can we encourage more collaborative and efficient research?
#computationalbiology #research #sciencepublishing #academia #bioinformatics

Richard Marshall
        
              
          One of the biggest issues with conventional software is capturing the expertise required to hand craft algorithms, error checking, validation and all the other complex knowledge that goes into software engineering. Capturing good quality requirements is exceptionally difficult for a number of reasons, but often because of the communication barrier between two highly specialized disciplines. It's possible that AI models and their blending of code and data into a single solution may provide a route to ensure better capture of complex needs, be they in healthcare, pharma, law or other disciplines. In any case, we're just at the beginning of the Applied AI journey.

Nicholas King
        
              
          𝗛𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗔𝗜 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗦𝘄𝗶𝗳𝘁 𝗚𝗲𝗻𝗲 𝗘𝗱𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴

Recent research published in Nature by Ming Y. Lu, Bowen Chen, and Drew F. K. Williamson, introduced an AI-driven tool that accelerates CRISPR-based gene editing. 

The approach combined the deep subject matter expertise of the team and augmenting this with models to enhance precision and efficiency of gene editing. Which then enables prediction of optimal CRISPR-Cas9 target sites, minimizing off-target effects and maximizing editing success.

A key aspect of this advancement is the applied AI methodology, which integrates multi-modal datasets—combining genomic, proteomic, and phenotypic data. This comprehensive data integration, coupled with subject matter expertise, enables the AI to make highly accurate predictions and refine gene-editing strategies. The synergy between AI and expert knowledge accelerates the development of precise and effective genetic modifications.

This breakthrough has implications for a wide range of genetic conditions. Diseases such as cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, and muscular dystrophy, which are caused by specific genetic mutations, can potentially be treated more effectively with precise gene-editing techniques. 

Additionally, complex conditions like cancer, where multiple genetic factors are at play, could see advancements in targeted therapies, leading to personalized and more effective treatment options. The ability to edit genes with high precision opens new avenues for addressing rare genetic disorders, previously deemed untreatable, and accelerates the path toward innovative cures and interventions.

https://lnkd.in/gV6YkzFH

#GeneEditing #CRISPR #AI #Biotechnology #ResearchInnovation #AppliedAI #MultiModalData #GeneticConditions #PersonalizedMedicine

Olivier Gomez (𝐎𝐆)
        
              
          Jensen Huang, in a talk at Berkeley, predicts that the next major revolution in technology will stem from digital biology. He emphasizes that for the first time in history, biology has the potential to transition from being a scientific discipline to an engineering field. Huang believes that this shift will lead to exponential improvements and compounding benefits, akin to advancements in computer science.

Highlighting the significance of this intersection, Huang describes the transformative impact it will have on the field of biology. By integrating tools from computer science, he envisions a future where the complexities of biology can be better understood and manipulated. This, he argues, will open up a plethora of opportunities and create a vast industry ripe for innovation.

For students and enthusiasts interested in this intersection, Huang sees a promising landscape filled with opportunities for groundbreaking discoveries and advancements. He encourages individuals to explore this emerging field, suggesting that it will be instrumental in shaping the future of technology and society.

Full credit to @berkeleyhaas @startupbell who is OG Approved!

Eric Bonabeau
        
              
          Augment and Invent ✨ 


💡 In a recent substack post (https://lnkd.in/g4iCuVaY), the always insightful Rishad Tobaccowala presents "10 thoughts about AI, Humans and Work in 10 minutes". They are all worth pondering (although I would not invoke Suleyman in # 3) but one that struck a chord with me, Thought # 6, summarizes two important themes: human augmentation and business (re)invention. Here is the thought:

"6. The simpler questions are about efficiency and effectiveness. The real question is more existential. AI will deliver efficiencies by getting things done faster and cheaper and as importantly more effectively by unleashing insights and freeing talent to work on areas where humans excel and let the math and pattern finding and the rest be done by the machine. But the smart companies are thinking about how to re-invent, re-imagine and re-think their business. In the world we live today with distributed and unbundled work, next generation technologies and multi-polar globalization why are more companies not re-imagining their businesses versus just focussing on making yesterdays model cheaper and more effective?"

Obvious pockets of inefficiencies will be addressed with #AI in the short term by businesses, thereby quickly eliminating any competitive advantage (a point made very nicely by Martin Reeves in a recent HBR article https://lnkd.in/gsaHk4V2). Any sustainable advantage will have to come from new ideas about augmentation (that amplify a company's unique assets) and from novel ideas in general for businesses. 

So, first, augmentation. I have been for 25 years a proponent of thinking about "unleashing insights and freeing talent to work on areas where humans excel and let the math and pattern finding and the rest be done by the machine". What is missing from a lot of the discourse on augmentation is what form it should take, specifically, how do humans and AIs interface? The chatbot form factor has been surprisingly effective (surprising to me at least) at opening floodgates of creativity from all kinds of horizons. It can't be the last frontier of human-AI interfacing. That needs to be invented.

Which takes us to the second part: (re)invention. The winners will use #genAI to create new products, services, experiences that are not even conceivable without AI. Business model disruption driven by AI is just beginning. When you product or service can be 80% replaced by a self-serve AI-based version at 0.001% of the cost, you have to seriously rethink where you create value. And as Rishad Tobaccowala writes in thought # 7, "A company’s best opportunities and threats are likely come from outside its immediate category and AI allows it to extend into new areas."

Freedom Preetham
        
              
          My ongoing research is in the area of long-term memory and accumulated experiences as part of the cognitive reasoning capability for AGI models (enable Cognitive Reasoning). This is my secondary research. My primary research is in the area of simulating Gene Regulatory Network within a biological cell. 

Here is part 3 in the series that gives a primer on Randomized algorithms that comes in handy. Randomized algorithms have fundamentally altered the landscape of spectral decomposition in high-dimensional PDEs. They have turned the impossible into the possible, allowing us to tackle problems of a scale and complexity that were once beyond our computational reach. By continuing to refine these techniques and exploring new applications, we pave the way for exciting advancements in mathematics, science, and engineering.

Michael Priddis
        
              
          This is a genuine call for considered pov's please.

Last week scientists from Fudan University in Shanghai published a paper "Frontier Al systems have surpassed the self-replicating red line". Highlighted abstract below c/o Dr. Michael G. Kollo. 

I replied to MK that this is clearly a concern, however noted that big tech is now also geopolitics in my reply to him: 

"Very interesting, I'm wondering how credible the source is to then work out how alarmed I should be. I know it’s Uni published and by academics however also note the current China vs NVIDIA case, US / China tariffs issue, ByteDance failing recently in preserving TikTok in US, and how Chinese Gov controls academia in a way that’s not seen in the West, so there’s some ‘structural scepticism’ here on my part as to whether this is real or part of China’s moves to pressure or slow US big tech, which is moving faster in AI R&D than China is, by amplifying risks."

[Update, following some of today’s comments: it might also just not be very good research, though as someone notes below, the university in question is a good one so if it’s published it’s credible on the face of it.]

So, does anyone here have a pov on this? And, if we think this paper is correct, what should the response be?

Freedom Preetham
        
              
          Worlfram does not have the best SDE solvers. (I caught him off guard on this today on a zoom presentation)!

I’ve encountered persistent roadblocks when attempting to execute stochastic differentials (SDEs) with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions on Wolfram Alpha. These equations extend well beyond the capabilities of symbolic solvers, and even Wolfram's numerical solvers buckle under the computational demands, halting progress altogether. Tackling these complex equations calls for an entirely new class of models designed to handle their intricacies. There is some ground up thinking required for SDEs honestly.

For simple stochastic differentials or low-dimensional problems, it’s feasible to attempt a numerical approximation using Wolfram's numerical solvers, especially if one breaks down the SDE or imposes approximations that simplify the boundary behavior.

I am also not a believer in the "Computational Universe" framework. I have attached a blog below. In this piece, I examine Stephen Wolfram's concept of a "computational universe," where simple computational rules, like cellular automata, are proposed to generate the universe's complexity. While I find Wolfram’s approach inspiring, offering fresh insights into complexity science and interdisciplinary modeling, I also see challenges it faces from established scientific theories. 

I contrast it with chaos theory's intrinsic unpredictability, quantum mechanics' probabilistic framework, and general relativity's continuous fabric of spacetime. Moreover, I find that mathematical constraints, such as Gödel's incompleteness theorem and Noether’s theorem on conservation laws, highlight limits to Wolfram's computational determinism, prompting me to question its alignment with physical reality.

#Math #Physics #Science #Innovation

Justin Hodges, PhD

Sam Farid
        
              
          This is a fascinating paper evaluating DeepMind’s AlphaFold 3 and its approach to predicting ligand docking: https://lnkd.in/gieM2nW5

The authors used a clever method to evaluate AlphaFold, finding that it can make glaring mistakes when placing molecules in binding sites because its model is likely only fitted to the protein’s backbone geometry instead of actually learning the underlying physical interactions.

Not that AlphaFold isn’t a breakthrough technology for drug discovery, but this paper highlights that even the most cutting-edge applications of AI are perhaps still best used to generate candidates, but humans still need to perform robust tests to validate them.

We’ve been hearing a similar sentiment from nearly all of our users when bringing AI into cloud infrastructure management. Flightcrew has been read-only from the start, using AI to generate insights but requiring a human to sign off before any changes are applied to their infrastructure. The goal is to speed up existing workflows, not create a new point of failure.

Drug discovery and managing Kubernetes are completely different applications but we’re all similarly wary of trusting full AI automation and at this rate, likely will be for some time.

Frédéric Barbaresco
        
              
          Machine Learning boosted by Natural Gradient of Information Geometry and Lie algebra
Paper: https://lnkd.in/esdqMRGd

"A framework for designing (non-diagonal) adaptive training methods" at IPAM's Theory and Practice of Deep Learning Workshop.
Abstract: Optimization is an essential ingredient of deep learning. Many optimization problems can be reformulated from a probabilistic perspective to exploit the Fisher-Rao (Riemannian) geometric structure of a probability family. In this talk, we show how to design new quasi-Newton methods for large-scale neural network (NN) training by leveraging the geometric structure. We first establish a second-order view of adaptive methods such as RMSProp and full-matrix AdaGrad when the square root is removed from their preconditioned gradient step. After that, we introduce and use preconditioner invariance to make non-diagonal adaptive methods inverse-free while keeping their preconditioner structures for modern mini-batches training with low precision. Finally, we propose Kronecker-factored adaptive methods to bridge the computation gap between non-diagonal and diagonal adaptive methods and demonstrate the advantages of our methods for training large NNs in half-precision by removing numerically unstable and computationally intensive matrix decompositions and inversions.

Cierra Choucair

💉 Alnylam Pharmaceuticals announced that its heart drug, vutrisiran, showed positive Phase 3 results, reducing the risk of death and recurrent cardiovascular complications by 28% compared to placebo.

🔍 BenevolentAI and AstraZeneca's collaboration progresses with the addition of a novel target for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) to AstraZeneca's discovery portfolio, showcasing the success of BenevolentAI’s AI-driven drug discovery platform.

🔬 Proscia partners with Nucleai to integrate AI-driven predictive biomarkers into Proscia's Concentriq® platform, enhancing precision medicine by providing advanced diagnostics and optimizing clinical trial execution

This collaboration aims to transform medication prescription practices globally by integrating advanced AI and genomic data analysis.

Balamurali A R, PhD
        
              
          
Just a few months ago, we were training on a curated set of genetic research papers from arXiv. These LLMs have been invaluable for our internal research, empowering scientists to understand how different traits and SNP interact for a particular health objective. 

However, keeping pace with this ever-evolving field presents two key challenges:
The data deluge: arXiv churns out thousands of new papers daily, making it impossible to constantly retrain our LLMs with the latest findings.

The model release frenzy: New LLM architectures and fine-tuned models appear on platforms like Hugging Face at a dizzying rate. How can we leverage these advancements without starting from scratch every time?
How do you solve this problem?: model merging!
Imagine this: hundreds of specialized models, some focusing on the exact dataset we need, are readily available on Hugging Face. What if we could combine the strengths of these pre-trained models with our own, leveraging tools like "mergekit"? This powerful tool allows anyone to merge a million-dollar trained model with a specialized one on a regular 16GB CPU machine using sharding. The entire process can take as little as 30 minutes!
This opens up a world of possibilities:
Reduced Training Costs: Say goodbye to expensive, time-consuming retraining! Merging pre-trained models allows us to incorporate the latest advancements efficiently.
Faster Innovation: By leveraging existing models, we can focus on fine-tuning and customization, accelerating our research and development cycles.
Democratization of AI: Mergekit empowers researchers of all levels to tap into the power of advanced LLMs without needing access to massive compute resources.
The future of LLM development is collaborative and efficient. By embracing model merging, we can unlock the full potential of this technology and accelerate scientific progress! #AI #LLMs #MachineLearning #Research

Freedom Preetham
        
              
          I just published > "Part 4 - Non Local Interactions in AGI through Weighted Choquard Equation"

In the pursuit of building Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), integrating long-term memory and accumulated experiences into cognitive reasoning is crucial for developing systems that can adapt and learn like humans. Traditional AI models often fall short in this aspect, focusing more on pattern recognition than on experiential learning. 

The weighted Choquard Equation offers a sophisticated mathematical framework that can model these non-local interactions, enabling AGI to maintain a dynamic, experience-based memory system. This approach not only captures long-range dependencies and prioritizes significant experiences but also ensures stability and coherence in memory integration, providing a new paradigm for cognitive reasoning in AGI.

#AGI #AI #Math #ArtificialIntelligence

https://lnkd.in/gVykvyjY

In a groundbreaking stride towards the future, research in artificial intelligence (AI) and robotics is progressively blurring the lines between living organisms and machines. Innovations like AI-driven prosthetic limbs and brain-machine interfaces are not just futuristic concepts but are evolving to replicate human bodily functions with remarkable fidelity. These advancements promise to offer unprecedented medical solutions for individuals grappling with illness or injury.
Yet, the quest for seamless integration of mechanical actuators with the human body calls for the development of sophisticated sensors. Imagine a sensor so advanced that it can stretch across both the body and mechanical components, akin to a second skin. This is where electronic skin (e-skin) enters the scene, poised to dissolve the once-clear boundary between organism and machine.
Highlighted on page 735 of this issue, Wang et al. report the development of a neuromorphic e-skin system that astonishingly mimics the sensory feedback of our biological skin. 

This is not just a step but a leap forward in the realm of neuro-robotics and prosthetics, setting the stage for a future where the line between the organic and the artificial becomes indistinguishable.

👇 Read the full article

Muhammad Arslan Shaukat
        
              
          📢 Academic Integrity: A Growing Concern (Part 2)

Unlike traditional journals, preprint services (like arXiv, bioRxiv & medRxiv, EarthArXiv Preprint Service, Research Square) allow researchers to share their work without undergoing the typical peer review process. While this accelerates the sharing of ideas and collaboration, it also means there is less oversight, potentially allowing anyone to upload content without stringent checks.

The integrity of citation metrics is crucial because these metrics play a significant role in how scientists are ranked and recognized globally. One such ranking is Stanford University and Elsevier top 2% Scientists list, which identifies scholars who are top-cited in their respective fields. This ranking is based on an analysis of citation impact across multiple scientific fields and subfields. Being included in such a list is a mark of distinction for researchers, and unethical practices like artificial citation manipulation can threaten the integrity of these rankings, misrepresenting the true impact of a scholar's work.

🛡️ Here are some steps we can take to address these issues:
 
📩 Contact Support: Reach out to support teams of these platforms with detailed information if you notice any misuse of citations.
🗂️ Document Incidents: Keep records of artificial papers and any communication with the platform, which can be useful if the issue escalates.
🏫 Inform Academic Institutions: Academic institutions can offer support and may help address such issues on a larger scale.
🧑‍⚖️ Consider Legal Advice: If misuse persists or causes reputational damage, exploring legal options might be necessary.

          2024 Earth Prize Winner - Leader of Team FloodGatehttps://www.theearthprize.org/the-earth-prize-20242024 Earth Prize Finalist Recipient (1/10) - Leader of Team FloodGatehttps://www.theearthprize.org/finalists2024 Earth Prize Scholar Recipient (1/35) - Leader of Team FloodGate https://www.theearthprize.org/scholars#floodgate2023 Earth Prize Scholar Recipient (1/37) - Leader of Team CleanMe!https://www.theearthprize.org/2023-scholars#clean-me!Invited to the 2024 Villars Symposium held in Ollon, Switzerland on June 25-28th, 2024."The Villars Institute was established in 2022 as a nonprofit foundation to accelerate the transition to a net zero and nature positive economy and to restore the health of the planet. Located in the Swiss Alps, the Villars Institute is a platform for systemic change and a place for intergenerational collaboration. It is also a curator of artistic, cultural, and educational activities that promote biodiversity, planetary health, and sustainable development.The Villars Symposium brings together the Institute’s partners and leading experts with the Villars Fellows to begin their life-long development as systems leaders."

awards.summary:
1/2 National Winners;1/12 National Finalists (Southeast Region Winner);1/100 State Winners (NC State Winner);1/25,000+ School Winners (NCSSM Winner);"The Heisman® High School Scholarship was created in 1994 through a partnership between Wendy’s® and The Heisman Trophy Trust. From its inception, the program has leveraged the reputation of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as a symbol of great ability combined with diligence, perseverance, and hard work.The Heisman High…
            

    
    

    
        Show more

          
    
  
      
          1/2 National Winners;1/12 National Finalists (Southeast Region Winner);1/100 State Winners (NC State Winner);1/25,000+ School Winners (NCSSM Winner);"The Heisman® High School Scholarship was created in 1994 through a partnership between Wendy’s® and The Heisman Trophy Trust. From its inception, the program has leveraged the reputation of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as a symbol of great ability combined with diligence, perseverance, and hard work.The Heisman High School Scholarship program extends the Heisman prestige to the nation’s most esteemed high school seniors by celebrating and rewarding outstanding male and female scholar-athletes who understand that the most important victories happen not only on the field, but also in their schools and communities.Over the past 28 years, the program has honored more than 600,000 of the nation’s most esteemed high school seniors and provided hundreds of thousands of dollars in college scholarships to students and more than a million dollars to high school academic and athletic programs across the country.The Heisman High School Scholarship program honors the nation’s most accomplished, community-minded high school senior athletes. By inviting male and female students from schools across the country to share their stories of leadership and impact, the program aims to inspire all students to harness their potential, push their limits, and use their talents not only to advance their own futures, but to improve the communities and world around them."
